title: 112_hr1873
content: The "Arbitration Fairness Act of 2011" may be cited as the Act. It includes findings related to arbitration. The Congress finds that the Federal Arbitration Act was originally intended for disputes between commercial entities but has now been expanded to consumer and employment disputes. This expansion limits the choices of consumers and employees, often without their knowledge, and undermines public law due to lack of transparency and judicial review in arbitration. Arbitration is a viable option when consent is voluntary and occurs after the dispute arises, but there are concerns about inadequate judicial review of arbitrators' decisions. Title 9 of the United States Code is amended to include a new chapter on arbitration of employment, consumer, and civil rights disputes. The new chapter in Title 9 of the United States Code defines a civil rights dispute as a disagreement related to discrimination based on race, sex, disability, religion, national origin, or other factors in various areas such as education, employment, and government programs. The new chapter in Title 9 of the United States Code defines a civil rights dispute as a disagreement related to discrimination based on race, sex, disability, religion, national origin, or other factors in various areas such as education, employment, and government programs. The term 'consumer dispute' refers to a disagreement between an individual seeking or acquiring property, services, money, or credit for personal use and the seller or provider. An 'employment dispute' is a conflict between parties related to employment issues. The term 'employment dispute' refers to a conflict between an employer and employee as defined in the Fair Labor Standards Act. A 'predispute arbitration agreement' is any agreement to arbitrate a dispute that had not yet arisen. No predispute arbitration agreement shall be valid or enforceable if it requires arbitration of an employment dispute, consumer dispute, or civil rights dispute. The applicability of this chapter to an agreement shall be determined under Federal law. Federal law determines the validity and enforceability of arbitration agreements. This chapter does not apply to arbitration provisions in collective bargaining agreements. Employees retain the right to seek judicial enforcement of their rights under the Constitution or State constitution. The validity and enforceability of arbitration agreements are determined by federal law, not applicable to collective bargaining agreements. Employees can still seek judicial enforcement of their rights under the Constitution or State constitution. Amendments are made to Title 9 of the United States Code, including changes to sections 1, 2, and 208. Amendments are made to Title 9 of the United States Code, including changes to sections 1, 2, and 208. Chapter 2 of title 9 is amended by striking the item relating to section 208 and inserting new language. Amendments to Title 9 of the United States Code include changes to section 307, adding a new chapter 4 for arbitration of employment, consumer, and civil rights disputes. The Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment and apply to disputes or claims arising after that date.
